results.title: Charlie Chaplin
results.brief_description: Charlie Chaplin is one of the most important people in the history of cinema. From The Kid (1921) to Modern Times (1936), his filmography features groundbreaking and critically acclaimed movies.
results.description:
Charlie Chaplin is one of the most important people in the history of cinema. From The Kid (1921) to Modern Times (1936), his filmography features groundbreaking and critically acclaimed movies.

Aside from being a writer, director, composer and producer, Chaplin is best known as a comic performer and was the first person to popularise feature-length comedies. His slapstick vagrant character ‘the Tramp’ is one of the most iconic performances in movie history and embodies Chaplin’s compassion for the downtrodden. His films often made fun of the wealthy and powerful, likely contributing to Chaplin being blacklisted from Hollywood in 1948 for having Communist sympathies.
description_for_label:
Charlie Chaplin is one of the most important people in the history of cinema. From The Kid (1921) to Modern Times (1936), his filmography features groundbreaking and critically acclaimed movies.

Aside from being a writer, director, composer and producer, Chaplin is best known as a comic performer and was the first person to popularise feature-length comedies. His slapstick vagrant character ‘the Tramp’ is one of the most iconic performances in movie history and embodies Chaplin’s compassion for the downtrodden. His films often made fun of the wealthy and powerful, likely contributing to Chaplin being blacklisted from Hollywood in 1948 for having Communist sympathies.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-04. Materiality → MI-04-C01

results.title: Auguste and Louis Lumière
results.brief_description: In 1895 Auguste and Louis Lumière patented the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity, but its biggest achievement was projection.

constellations_primary.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_primary.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

results.description:
After learning about Thomas Edison’s Kinetograph in the early 1890s, Auguste and Louis Lumière set out to free motion pictures from Edison’s bulky contraption. In 1895 they succeeded, patenting the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity. But its biggest achievement was projection: while only one person could look through the Kinetograph’s peephole at a time, audiences could watch Cinématographe films together.

Alongside their invention, the Lumière brothers premiered 10 short films on daily life, known as actualités, including the famous Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896). The Cinématographe even inspired the new art form’s name: cinema.
description_for_label:
After learning about Thomas Edison’s Kinetograph in the early 1890s, Auguste and Louis Lumière set out to free motion pictures from Edison’s bulky contraption. In 1895 they succeeded, patenting the Cinématographe, which could record, develop and project film. The Lumière brothers’ all-in-one device was lightweight, portable and operated by hand crank instead of electricity. But its biggest achievement was projection: while only one person could look through the Kinetograph’s peephole at a time, audiences could watch Cinématographe films together.

Alongside their invention, the Lumière brothers premiered 10 short films on daily life, known as actualités, including the famous Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896). The Cinématographe even inspired the new art form’s name: cinema.

results.title: Alice Guy-Blaché
results.brief_description: Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio. She made hundreds of films between during her career, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux

constellations_primary.name: Lost and found
constellations_primary.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

results.description:
Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio, Solax. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage Fairy, 1896).

Guy-Blaché later experimented with early synchronised sound, colour and special effects, often filming on location with hundreds of extras. In 1912 she made A Fool and His Money, widely believed to be the first film to have an all–African American cast.

To find our more about Alice Guy-Blaché, rent Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché on our streaming platform, Cinema 3.
description_for_label:
Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio, Solax. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage Fairy, 1896).

Guy-Blaché later experimented with early synchronised sound, colour and special effects, often filming on location with hundreds of extras. In 1912 she made A Fool and His Money, widely believed to be the first film to have an all–African American cast.

results.title: Loads on structures
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: Robert Heller discusses static and dynamic loads. He describes the deformations and stresses that they are produced by dynamic oscillation and presents news footage which shows the disastrous effects of loads on structures. Includes scenes of the collapse of the Tacoma Narrows bridge;”Years 7-12”

results.title: Job enrichment in action
results.brief_description: “Summary: frederick herzberg explains that according to his motivation-hygiene theory, it is the job content which is directly related to motivation, and that job content must be enriched to allow more responsibility and encourage individual achievement. uses an actual case to point out some of the most common problems of successful job enrichment”

results.title: Indian family : modern Mayan
results.brief_description: “Summary: shows the life of a Mexican Indian family in calipash, where the Indians live in much the same way as did their Mayan ancestors. centres on the father who is a teacher in the local school and an important man in the community”

results.title: India : population 600 million
results.brief_description: “SUMMARY: A review of efforts to introduce family planning to India indicates that poverty in the rural areas is the major problem and until it is controlled to some extent there seems little hope of a successful implementation of any form of birth control in these areas”

results.title: Gregor Mendel
results.brief_description: “Summary: R.M. Eakin dramatizes the discoveries, method of study, theory & personal philosophy of scientist gregor mendel. explains his interest in heredity and why he selected the edible pea for his experiments”
